title: Brisbane Heat cruise past Sydney Thunder to reach fourth WBBL final
description: Grace Parsons took 3-10 to break back of Sydney battingGeorgia Redmayne 50 sets up showdown with RenegadesBrisbane Heat are through to their fourth WBBL decider after legspinner Grace Parsons broke the back of the Sydney Thunder batting line-up in another slick exhibition of her craft.Heat’s captain, Jess Jonassen, sent the Thunder in at Allan Border Field and marshalled her bowlers to perfection as the visitors crashed to 7-69. author: Australia Associated Press
excerpt: Grace Parsons took 3-10 to break back of Sydney batting, while Georgia Redmayne sees Heat into showdown with Renegades
text: Brisbane Heat are through to their fourth WBBL decider after legspinner Grace Parsons broke the back of the Sydney Thunder batting line-up in another slick exhibition of her craft.Heat’s captain, Jess Jonassen, sent the Thunder in at Allan Border Field and marshalled her bowlers to perfection as the visitors crashed to 7-69.A record WBBL stand of 64 for the eighth wicket by Hannah Darlington (40 not out) and Taneale Peschel (24 not out) lifted the Thunder to 7-133.But the Heat polished off the runs in 15.2 overs for a nine-wicket win to set up a WBBL final showdown away against Melbourne Renegades at the MCG on Sunday.India international Jemimah Rodrigues was dropped three times, two of them sitters, on her way to a skilled 43 off 30 deliveries before retiring hurt. She combined with opener Georgia Redmayne, who scored an unbeaten 50, to set up the run chase.Rodrigues had injured her left wrist in the field and had to retire in the 10th over. She is a doubt for the final but Redmayne and Charli Knott (19 not out) at least showcased the Heat’s depth.Parsons, 21, earlier took 3-10 in three classy overs to set up her side’s sixth straight win.Thunder opener, Georgia Voll, was looking good against her former side before chopping on to the first ball of Nicola Hancock’s spell for 20.Jonassen showed immediately why she was named in the WBBL team of the decade when she cleaned up Chamari Athapaththu with her first delivery, a beauty that drifted in and spun away.Wicketkeeper Tahlia Wilson holed out to Parsons and the visitors stumbled to 3-51.Parsons snared the key wicket of skipper Phoebe Litchfield who was brilliantly caught by Jonassen at mid-off for 15 as she leapt high and snaffled a well hit drive above her head.And Parsons had two in the over when Georgia Adams skied one.Jonassen snared former Heat allrounder, Sammy-Jo Johnson, and at 7-69 the Thunder were in dire straits before Darlington and Peschel lifted them to a competitive total.Both posted their career-best scores and unleashed an array of sixes and fours in the latter overs.The stand broke the previous record of 60, also unbeaten, set by Lauren Ebsary and Piepa Cleary in 2018 for Perth Scorchers against Melbourne Renegades.The Heat lost Grace Harris (7), stumped early after a wild heave, to give Sam Bates her 20th wicket of the season. Redmayne and Rodrigues then ensured the hosts were able to cruise to victory.
html:
Brisbane Heat are through to their fourth WBBL decider after legspinner Grace Parsons broke the back of the Sydney Thunder batting line-up in another slick exhibition of her craft.

Heat’s captain, Jess Jonassen, sent the Thunder in at Allan Border Field and marshalled her bowlers to perfection as the visitors crashed to 7-69.

A record WBBL stand of 64 for the eighth wicket by Hannah Darlington (40 not out) and Taneale Peschel (24 not out) lifted the Thunder to 7-133.

But the Heat polished off the runs in 15.2 overs for a nine-wicket win to set up a WBBL final showdown away against Melbourne Renegades at the MCG on Sunday.

India international Jemimah Rodrigues was dropped three times, two of them sitters, on her way to a skilled 43 off 30 deliveries before retiring hurt. She combined with opener Georgia Redmayne, who scored an unbeaten 50, to set up the run chase.

Rodrigues had injured her left wrist in the field and had to retire in the 10th over. She is a doubt for the final but Redmayne and Charli Knott (19 not out) at least showcased the Heat’s depth.

Parsons, 21, earlier took 3-10 in three classy overs to set up her side’s sixth straight win.

Thunder opener, Georgia Voll, was looking good against her former side before chopping on to the first ball of Nicola Hancock’s spell for 20.

Jonassen showed immediately why she was named in the WBBL team of the decade when she cleaned up Chamari Athapaththu with her first delivery, a beauty that drifted in and spun away.

Wicketkeeper Tahlia Wilson holed out to Parsons and the visitors stumbled to 3-51.

Parsons snared the key wicket of skipper Phoebe Litchfield who was brilliantly caught by Jonassen at mid-off for 15 as she leapt high and snaffled a well hit drive above her head.

And Parsons had two in the over when Georgia Adams skied one.

Jonassen snared former Heat allrounder, Sammy-Jo Johnson, and at 7-69 the Thunder were in dire straits before Darlington and Peschel lifted them to a competitive total.

Both posted their career-best scores and unleashed an array of sixes and fours in the latter overs.

The stand broke the previous record of 60, also unbeaten, set by Lauren Ebsary and Piepa Cleary in 2018 for Perth Scorchers against Melbourne Renegades.

The Heat lost Grace Harris (7), stumped early after a wild heave, to give Sam Bates her 20th wicket of the season. Redmayne and Rodrigues then ensured the hosts were able to cruise to victory.
